column4: 1. Life    - Definition: A characteristic that distinguishes physical entities with biological processes like signaling and self-sustaining processes from those that do not, either because such functions have ceased (death), or because they have not developed such functions and are classified as inanimate.    2. Origin of Life        - Panspermia: Theory suggesting that life spread across the universe via meteoroids, asteroids, comets, spacecraft, etc.        - Primordial Soup Theory: Theory suggesting that life began in a pond or ocean as a result of the combination of chemicals from the atmosphere and some form of energy.        - Deep Sea Vent Theory: Theory suggesting that life could have started in underwater habitats shielded from hostile conditions on the surface.    3. Characteristics of Life        - Metabolism: The ability of an organism to intake, transform and exchange energy.        - Adaptation: The ability of an organism to change over time in response to their environment.        - Reproduction: The ability of an organism to produce new individuals of its kind.        - Growth: The ability of an organism to increase its size or number of individuals.    4. Forms of Life        - Unicellular life: Life forms made up of a single cell like bacteria, archaea, etc.        - Multicellular life: Life forms made up of multiple cells like plants, animals, fungi, etc.        - Extraterrestrial Life: Hypothetical life forms that might exist outside the earth.        5. Life Stages        - Inception: Sexual reproduction or asexual reproduction.        - Growth: Embryo, infancy, childhood, adolescence, adulthood.        - Decline: Senescence, old age, death.    6. Life Span        - Short-lived: Life forms that only live for a few hours or days, like mayflies.        - Medium-lived: Life forms that live for several years or decades, like humans.        - Long-lived: Life forms that live for hundreds or even thousands of years, like tortoises or trees.    7. Study of Life        - Biology: Broad study of living organisms.        - Microbiology: Study of microscopic organisms.        - Zoology: Study of animals and animal behavior.        - Botany: Study of plants and plant life.        - Virology: Study of viruses and virus-like agents.    8. Preservation of Life        - Healthcare: Medical practices targeted at maintaining or improving health.        - Conservation: Practices aimed at preserving natural habitats and biodiversity.        - Ethics: Philosophical discourse surrounding the rights and value of lives.        9. Termination of Life        - Death: Cessation of biological functions that sustain a living organism.        - Extinction: Complete disappearance of a species from existence.        - Euthanasia: Practice of intentionally ending life to relieve pain and suffering.    10. Meaning of Life        - Philosophical Question: The purpose or significance of life.        - Religious Beliefs: Different beliefs and teachings regarding the purpose of life.        - Scientific Perspectives: Life as a process of evolution and perpetuation of genes.
